case_vignette: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden shortness of breath. He was playing in the school garden and suddenly started to complain of abdominal pain. He then vomited a few times. An hour later in the hospital, he slowly developed a rash on his chest, arms, and legs. His breathing became faster with audible wheezing. On physical examination, his vital signs are as follows: the temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), the blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, the pulse is 130/min, and the respiratory rate is 25/min. A rash is on his right arm, as shown in the image. After being administered appropriate treatment, the boy improves significantly, and he is able to breathe comfortably.
question: Which  is the best marker that could be measured in the serum of this boy to help establish a definitive diagnosis?
